title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Can LLMs Master Cryptic Clues?
text:
For many puzzle enthusiasts, cryptic crosswords represent the pinnacle of clever wordplay. Crafting (and solving) cryptic clues requires two parts:

A definition of the answer
A wordplay hint (an anagram, hidden word, or another playful manipulation)

These two components are typically combined in a single short clue, creating a riddle that demands careful linguistic or logical parsing. The question we want to answer in this post is:

Can a Large Language Model (LLM) craft valid cryptic clues that both define the word and present correct wordplay?

Additionally, we will see if an LLM can interpret the rationale behind cryptic clues‚Äîessentially, can it solve them and provide a breakdown of the wordplay?

title: Can LLMs Master Cryptic Clues?
text:
Background on Cryptic Clues
A traditional (UK-style) cryptic clue has:

Definition part: A direct definition of the solution word/phrase (similar to a standard crossword clue).
Wordplay part: A set of instructions for how to manipulate letters (anagrams, hidden words, homophones, reversals, etc.) to arrive at the same solution.

For example, a classic short cryptic clue is:

Doctor in short supply (3)


The answer is DOC.
Definition: ‚ÄúDoctor‚Äù is the direct definition for ‚Äúdoc‚Äù.
Wordplay: ‚Äúin short supply‚Äù is instructing us to take ‚Äúsupply‚Äù and shorten it (suppl) or notice that ‚Äúin short‚Äù might be indicating to chop off the last letters. The exact mechanism can vary depending on style, but it usually references a form of truncation or pun.

title: Can LLMs Master Cryptic Clues?
section: Prompting an LLM to Create Cryptic Clues
text:
Prompting an LLM to Create Cryptic Clues
We experimented with prompting a well-known LLM (we used GPT-4 in this case, but you can attempt similar prompts with other models). Our prompt was structured to explain the concept:

‚ÄúPlease create a cryptic crossword clue for the word ACME. The clue must include a definition and a wordplay segment, in typical cryptic style.‚Äù


GPT-4‚Äôs Response
A top tip for Emily‚Äôs company (4)
Proposed Explanation: - Definition: ‚ÄúA top‚Äù is a concise definition for ACME (meaning the highest point). - Wordplay: ‚Äútip for Emily‚Äôs company‚Äù might be instructing us to take the first letter (tip) of ‚ÄúEmily‚Äù (E) plus a synonym for ‚Äúcompany‚Äù (e.g., C0 for ‚ÄòCo.‚Äô?), forming ‚ÄúE + C0‚Äù = ‚ÄúEC0‚Äù? That‚Äôs not exactly ACME.

title: Can LLMs Master Cryptic Clues?
text:
Conclusion

LLMs can approximate cryptic crossword clue styles, especially if you provide instructions on structure and examples.
Accuracy varies: Some attempts fail to connect the wordplay steps properly, indicating the complexity of cryptic logic.
Chain-of-Thought: When asked to explain the solution, LLMs often give plausible justifications, demonstrating how they might parse the puzzle.

Ultimately, cryptic crosswords demand exactness in logic, and LLMs are still prone to small mistakes in letter manipulation or wordplay instructions. However, with iterative prompts and examples, they can learn to craft passable (sometimes even excellent) cryptic clues‚Äîand solve them!
